study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of reflexology on pain, fatigue, and quality of life in Multiple Sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: Reflexology significantly reduced pain and fatigue scores from the fifth and seventh weeks, respectively, and improved quality of life scores in MS patients compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 66 MS patients (33 intervention, 33 control) diagnosed at least 6 months prior, from neurology clinics in two Turkish university hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of reflexology on relieving labour pain and assess patient satisfaction with the treatment.
results_summary: The study found that foot reflexology significantly reduced labour pain at 20 and 40 minutes post-intervention compared to the control group, with 81% of patients recommending it during labour.
population_specificity: 50 primigravida patients experiencing labour in a hospital setting.
effective_dosage: Foot reflexology applied to five pressure points of both feet for 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effects of foot reflexology on improving sleep disturbances in adults.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly improved sleep quality, with a notable reduction in sleep quality scores (Hedges' g = -1.37) and a lower likelihood of sleep problems in the intervention group (pooled odds ratio = 0.25). The findings suggest reflexology is an effective complementary therapy for sleep disturbances.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years old with sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foot reflexology could alleviate invasive pain in term neonates caused by heel lance.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly reduced pain scores (NIPS) and crying periods in neonates after heel lance, and had a notable effect on heart rate before the procedure, though it did not affect the duration of the heel lance itself.
population_specificity: Healthy term neonates (n=60, divided into reflexology and control groups).
effective_dosage: Foot reflexology for an average of 20 minutes before heel lance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of reflexology and body massage on physiological indicators and bilirubin levels in infants undergoing phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia.
results_summary: Reflexology and body massage significantly improved arterial oxygen saturation and bilirubin levels compared to the control group, but no significant differences were observed in heart rate or respiration rate.
population_specificity: Infants with jaundice at a pediatric medical center in Iran.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of reflexology or body massage once daily.
study_duration: The intervention was administered once daily for an unspecified number of days (implied short-term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of plantar reflexology on labor pain severity, childbirth experience, and duration of labor stages.
results_summary: Plantar reflexology significantly reduced labor pain severity in one intervention group compared to the control, but no significant differences were found between intervention groups or for childbirth experience. The third stage of labor was shorter in the reflexology groups.
population_specificity: 90 women in labor at Al-Zahra and Taleghani hospitals in Tabriz-Iran.
effective_dosage: Two 30-minute massages per participant (timing: at 4-cm and 7-cm cervical dilation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of reflexology on lactation in mothers who delivered by cesarean section.
results_summary: Reflexology significantly improved LATCH breastfeeding scores compared to the control group, with higher scores for lactation onset signs. No significant differences were found for some symptoms (breast heat, pain, tension) on certain days, but the intervention group showed overall better outcomes.
population_specificity: Postpartum women who delivered by cesarean section (n=60).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes total (10 minutes per foot), twice daily with 8-hour intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of foot reflexology on chest pain and anxiety in patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI).
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly reduced chest pain severity in the treatment group compared to control and placebo groups after 20 minutes, but no significant effect was observed on anxiety levels.
population_specificity: 90 patients with AMI, divided into treatment, placebo, and control groups.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes per session, for three consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between pain, spirituality, and engagement with a caregiver-delivered foot reflexology intervention in women with advanced breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that younger, unmarried, unemployed women or those receiving hormonal therapy had higher pain levels, while older, non-White, or Christian women reported higher spirituality. Spirituality did not significantly influence pain over time.
population_specificity: Women with advanced breast cancer (N = 256).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of foot reflexology on low back pain in operating room nurses.
results_summary: Reflexology significantly reduced low back pain in nurses after 4 weeks of treatment, with no change observed in the control group. The reflexology group showed significantly lower pain scores compared to the control group at week 5.
population_specificity: Operating room nurses with low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of foot reflexology for improving adult depression, anxiety, and sleep quality through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that foot reflexology significantly improved depression, anxiety, and sleep quality, with larger effect sizes for sleep quality. Increased reflexology time and duration further enhanced sleep quality improvements.
population_specificity: Adults suffering from depression, anxiety, or sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of foot reflexology in reducing blood pressure and heart rate in patients with stage-2 hypertension.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly reduced heart rate in stage-2 hypertension patients and showed partial effectiveness in reducing blood pressure, with notable decreases in systolic and diastolic BP at 15 and 30 minutes post-intervention. However, only the reduction in heart rate was significant when compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Stage-2 hypertension patients (n=47 per group).
study_duration: Single follow-up visit with measurements taken at 15 and 30 minutes post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of thermal imaging in tracking temperature changes during Reflexology lymph drainage (RLD) treatment for breast cancer-related lymphoedema (BCRL).
results_summary: Thermal imaging showed temperature differences in the affected hand and arm over 45 minutes, and Limb Volume Circumferential Measurement (LVCM) indicated a reduction in limb volume in the affected arm for both participants, which continued to decrease over 24 hours.
population_specificity: Two participants with breast cancer-related lymphoedema (BCRL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of reflexology on migraine symptoms under pragmatic, personally funded conditions.
results_summary: 75% of participants showed an improvement of two or more points in their MYMOP profile, and 90% achieved the minimal clinically important difference. The greatest improvement was in the primary symptom, with an average change of 3.40 points.
population_specificity: 20 reflexology clients with medically diagnosed migraine, self-referred to a member of the Association of Reflexologists (AoR).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but six sessions were administered.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether reflexology, as an adjunctive therapy to conventional asthma treatment, improves quality of life and asthma control.
results_summary: The study found minor improvements in asthma quality of life scores with reflexology, but these changes were not statistically significant. Reflexology did not demonstrate any meaningful difference in secondary outcomes compared to conventional treatment alone.
population_specificity: 86 asthma patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of reflexology and relaxation on pain, anxiety, depression, and quality of life in cancer patients.
results_summary: Reflexology significantly reduced anxiety and depression more than relaxation, improved quality of life (physical component), and showed a greater effect on pain management. Both interventions were effective, but reflexology had superior outcomes in several measures.
population_specificity: 88 cancer patients from an outpatient Palliative Care Unit in Attica, Greece.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of hand reflexology on pain and fatigue in patients after coronary angiography.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant differences in pain and fatigue scores between the intervention and control groups, with medium to large effects observed. Hand reflexology was deemed a safe and effective nonpharmacological technique for reducing pain and fatigue post-coronary angiography.
population_specificity: 90 patients in an angiography department of a referral hospital in an urban area of Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of foot reflexology on functional constipation through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly increased the curative ratio and improved constipation-related symptoms, though its effects on stool frequency, consistency, and compliance with toilet training, diet, and motivation were inconsistent or not significant. The evidence was insufficient to fully support its effectiveness in reducing recurrence rates.
population_specificity: Individuals with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foot reflexology reduces agitation and shortens extubation time in male patients after coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
results_summary: Foot reflexology significantly reduced agitation at immediate and 10-minute post-intervention assessments and shortened extubation time compared to placebo and control groups.
population_specificity: Male patients recovering from coronary artery bypass graft surgery (n = 120).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Reishi water extract could effectively reduce blood pressure and influence cerebral blood flow and neurotransmitter balance in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Reishi extract reduced blood pressure comparably to losartan and significantly increased cerebral blood flow while shifting neurotransmitter balance toward excitation, suggesting potential nootropic effects.
population_specificity: Adult male hypertensive ISIAH rats (inherited stress-induced arterial hypertension model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of foot reflexology massage on burn-specific pain anxiety and sleep quality in burn ICU patients.
results_summary: Foot reflexology massage significantly reduced pain anxiety and improved sleep quality (latency, duration, and satisfaction) in burn patients compared to routine care, with a large effect size (0.82) for pain anxiety reduction.
population_specificity: Burn patients hospitalized in the ICU.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of foot reflexology massage for 3 days (on days 3, 4, and 5 of hospitalization) and 15 minutes before wound dressing changes.
study_duration: 3 days (plus additional sessions before dressing changes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of foot reflexology on pain and anxiety severity in burn patients during dressing changes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain and anxiety between groups initially, but reflexology showed significant reductions in pain and anxiety on days 4-6 post-intervention compared to standard care alone.
population_specificity: 66 burn patients referred to Vali-e-asr Hospital, Arak, Iran.
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions, three times a week (Saturday, Monday, Wednesday).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foot reflexology could reduce pain and fatigue and improve sleep quality in patients after kidney transplantation.
results_summary: The study found that foot reflexology significantly reduced pain and fatigue and improved sleep quality compared to the control group, with statistically significant improvements (P < 0.001). No significant difference was observed in acetaminophen use between groups.
population_specificity: Patients admitted to a transplantation ward after kidney surgery.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes once a day for three consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) regarding its potential to enhance chemotherapeutic efficacy, reverse multidrug resistance, and reduce chemotherapeutic toxicity.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that Reishi contains bioactive compounds like terpenoids and polysaccharides with anticancer properties, and suggests potential benefits when combined with chemotherapy, though no systematic review has been conducted in this area.
population_specificity: Cancer patients using complementary alternative medicines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a combination of breathing exercises, foot reflexology, and back massage (BRM) on labour pain and anxiety in primigravidae.
results_summary: The abstract describes a study protocol, so no results are reported yet. The study will measure labour pain, anxiety, maternal stress hormone levels, vital signs, fetal heart rate, labour duration, Apgar scores, and maternal satisfaction.
population_specificity: Primigravidae at 26-34 weeks of gestation without chronic diseases or pregnancy-related complications.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involves BRM delivered by a trained massage therapist).
study_duration: BRM administered hourly for 2 hours post-baseline (cervical dilatation 6 cm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antimicrobial activity of Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) against various pathogens and evaluate its toxicity potential.
results_summary: The study found that Reishi exhibited antimicrobial activity with minimal inhibitory concentrations ranging from 200 to 400μg/ml. While no cytotoxicity was observed, genotoxicity was detected with metabolic activation, particularly at the highest concentration (5mg/ml).
population_specificity: In vitro testing on microbial strains and NIH3T3 cell lines.
effective_dosage: 200-400μg/ml for antimicrobial activity; up to 5mg/ml for toxicity testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effects of triterpenoids from Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) on liver injury induced by α-amanitin in mice and explore their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Reishi triterpenoids significantly reduced liver enzyme levels and mortality rates, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, and inhibited apoptosis, demonstrating hepatoprotective effects comparable to the reference drug silibinin.
population_specificity: Mice with α-amanitin-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits and reliability of Ganoderma Lucidum (Reishi) for health promotion and disease prevention, particularly its anticancer properties.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Reishi may have some benefits for cancer patients based on laboratory and preclinical studies, but clinical studies are limited and questionable. The authors recommend further research to identify active components and assess reliability before widespread use.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory and preclinical studies primarily mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether salicylic acid (SA) enhances ganoderic acid (GA) accumulation in Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) and how it affects key genes and metabolites in the GA biosynthesis pathway.
results_summary: SA treatment significantly increased GA content (up to 66.38% improvement) and upregulated key genes (squalene synthase, lanosterol synthase, and HMG-CoA reductase) and intermediate metabolites (lanosterol and squalene) in the GA biosynthesis pathway.
population_specificity: Ganoderma lucidum (fungal culture)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential of Reishi-enriched soap for treating annular cutaneous sarcoidosis.
results_summary: The patient showed almost complete regression of skin lesions after using Reishi-enriched soap for 3 days, suggesting potential efficacy in treating this condition.
population_specificity: 44-year-old male with annular cutaneous sarcoidosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (soap enriched with G. lucidum and goat's milk).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of G. lucidum on long-term survival, tumor response, immune function, and quality of life in cancer patients, as well as assess adverse events.
results_summary: G. lucidum showed potential benefits when combined with chemo/radiotherapy, improving tumor response and immune function markers, but did not demonstrate significant effects as a standalone treatment. Quality of life improved marginally, and adverse events were minimal and minor.
population_specificity: Cancer patients diagnosed by pathology, all types and stages included.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of supplementing sunflower seed hull substrate with olive oil and copper (II) on Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) mushroom production and triterpenoid content.
results_summary: Adding 1.5% olive oil increased total mushroom production by 21.7%, while 60 ppm copper improved first-flush productivity but reduced subsequent flushes. Combining both supplements boosted first-flush production by 43%, but no significant change in triterpenoid content was observed.
population_specificity: Cultivated Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) mushrooms.
effective_dosage: 1.5% olive oil and 60 ppm copper (II) in substrate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anticonvulsant, antidepressant-like, and anxiolytic-like effects of an aqueous extract from cultured Ganoderma lucidum mycelium in mice.
results_summary: The extract significantly increased the threshold for psychomotor seizures in the 6-Hz test and reduced immobility in the forced swim test, indicating potential anticonvulsant and antidepressant-like effects. No effects were observed in other seizure tests or anxiolytic-like behavior, and no toxic effects were reported.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hematological and antioxidant effects of an aqueous extract of Ganoderma lucidum fruiting bodies in Plasmodium berghei-infected mice.
results_summary: The extract significantly reduced serum malondialdehyde levels and increased antioxidant enzyme activities, suggesting potent antioxidant effects that protect hemoglobin against oxidative damage caused by Plasmodium infection.
population_specificity: Plasmodium berghei-infected mice
effective_dosage: 100, 250, and 500 mg/kg body weight, administered once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aqueous extracts of Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) from three different locations on human papillomavirus-transformed cervical cells and cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that Reishi extracts inhibited cell proliferation, induced apoptosis, and caused cell cycle arrest in HeLa, SiHa, and C-33A cancer cells, suggesting potential therapeutic use for cancer prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Human papillomavirus-transformed cervical cells (HeLa and SiHa) and C-33A cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of G. lucidum on long-term survival, tumour response, immune function, and quality of life in cancer patients, as well as assess adverse events.
results_summary: G. lucidum showed potential in enhancing tumour response when combined with chemo/radiotherapy and improved immune function indicators, but its standalone efficacy was unclear. Quality of life marginally improved, and adverse events were minimal.
population_specificity: Cancer patients diagnosed by pathology, all types and stages included.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effects of Ganoderma lucidum aqueous extracts (GLEs) on liver injury induced by α-amanitin in mice and analyze potential antioxidant-related mechanisms.
results_summary: GLE significantly reduced liver damage markers (ALT, AST), increased antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, CAT), and decreased oxidative stress (MDA) in mice with α-amanitin-induced liver injury, comparable to the reference drug silibinin. Histopathological findings supported these biochemical improvements.
population_specificity: Mice with α-amanitin-induced liver injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Reishi and its principal ingredient, β-glucan, on dendritic cell activation and Th17 cell differentiation.
results_summary: Reishi extracts and β-glucan activated dendritic cells, increasing IL-23 production, which in turn promoted Th17 cell differentiation both in vitro and in vivo. Orally administered Reishi also enhanced Th17 cell percentages and antimicrobial peptide transcription.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the teratogenic and toxic effects of Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) extract on zebrafish embryos.
results_summary: The study found that Reishi extract caused significant hatching delays, tail malformations, growth retardation, and increased mortality in zebrafish embryos, with effects worsening at higher concentrations (5% or more).
population_specificity: Zebrafish embryos

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immunomodulatory effects of LZ-8, a protein from Reishi, on T-cell proliferation and regulatory T-cell (Treg) expansion.
results_summary: LZ-8 induced significant expansion of FOXP3(+) Treg cells in both murine and human CD4(+) T cells, enhanced CTLA-4 and IL-10 expression, and alleviated DSS-induced colitis in mice via adoptive transfer of treated T cells. The mechanism involved CD45-mediated signaling and CD18-dependent IL-2 induction.
population_specificity: Murine and human primary CD4(+) T cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunostimulating activities of Reishi's beta-glucan (BGG), including its binding to dectin-1, cytokine secretion, and induction of Toll-like receptors in macrophages.
results_summary: BGG bound to dectin-1 and induced secretion of inflammatory cytokines in macrophages, which was further enhanced by lipopolysaccharide (LPS). It also increased nitric oxide production and upregulated TLR2, TLR4, and TLR6 expressions, suggesting activation of NF-kappaB pathways.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 mouse macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Reishi's polysaccharide component (MAK) could induce GM-CSF production and mitigate intestinal inflammation in a murine model of colitis.
results_summary: MAK stimulated GM-CSF production in vitro and in vivo, reduced intestinal inflammation, decreased IFN-γ, and increased GM-CSF in TNBS-induced colitis. The anti-inflammatory effect was blocked by GM-CSF neutralization.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with TNBS-induced colitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Reishi (Ganoderma lucidum) as an anti-inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) therapy by examining its effects on cell viability, apoptosis, invasion, and molecular mechanisms in IBC cells.
results_summary: Reishi selectively inhibited IBC cell viability, induced apoptosis, disrupted tumor spheroids, and reduced expression of genes linked to cancer survival, proliferation, invasion, and metastasis while increasing IL8 expression. It also decreased key protein expression and gelatinase activity.
population_specificity: Inflammatory breast cancer cells (SUM-149) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Reishi polysaccharides (EORP) affect the interaction between LPS and murine macrophages, specifically focusing on TLR4 and CD14 receptor expression, LPS binding, and phagocytosis.
results_summary: The study found that EORP pretreatment enhanced macrophage surface expression of TLR4 and CD14, increased LPS binding and phagocytosis, and altered the binding dynamics by reducing adhesion time and increasing force constants.
population_specificity: Murine macrophages (J774A.1 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the distinct immunomodulatory roles of Reishi's polysaccharide (PS-G) and protein (LZ-8) components in activating innate and adaptive immunity.
results_summary: The study found that LZ-8 activated both macrophages and T lymphocytes, enhancing cytokine production and cell surface marker expression, while PS-G primarily activated macrophages via TLR4 without affecting T cells. These results suggest LZ-8 and PS-G have divergent roles in immune regulation.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) primary macrophages and T lymphocytic cells, including TLR4-deficient and wild-type mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanistic effects of Reishi on the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway and its potential as a therapeutic for Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC).
results_summary: Reishi reduced IBC cell viability, invasion, and expression of key molecules (eIF4G, E-cadherin, mTOR, p70S6K), suppressed protein synthesis, and decreased tumor growth by ~50% in mice. It also affected survival and proliferative signaling pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro IBC SUM-149 cells and in vivo severe combined immunodeficient mice injected with IBC cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a water-soluble extract from Reishi mycelia (MAK) could protect the small intestine against damage caused by various anti-cancer drugs.
results_summary: MAK protected against small intestinal injury induced by 5-fluorouracil (5FU), UFT, and cisplatin (CDDP), and enhanced crypt regeneration when combined with cyclophosphamide (CPA) or gefitinib (Iressa). Agaricus blazei Murrill (AGA) did not show similar protective effects.
population_specificity: Six-week-old male B6C3F1/Crlj mice.
study_duration: One week before anti-cancer drug treatment until 3.5 days post-injection.
interactions: Interacted with 5FU, UFT, CDDP, CPA, and gefitinib (Iressa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary MAK (Reishi extract) supplementation on lung tumor development in rats initiated by a carcinogen.
results_summary: MAK supplementation reduced lung tumor nodules, with the 5% dose showing significant effects. Microscopic analysis revealed fewer proliferating tumors in MAK-treated groups, suggesting chemopreventive potential.
population_specificity: Male Slc:Wistar rats, 6 weeks old

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the biological effects of Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) on specific signaling molecules and pathways responsible for its therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study highlights that Reishi contains biologically active polysaccharides with immunostimulatory properties contributing to anticancer effects, along with other bioactive substances like triterpenes, proteins, and phenols. These components are implicated in various therapeutic benefits, though specific clinical outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general reference to historical use in China, Korea, and Japan).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immuno-potentiating effects of Reishi (Rokkaku-Reishi) on Th1-associated immune responses in mice.
results_summary: Oral administration of 500 mg/kg Reishi significantly increased IFN-gamma and IL-12 production, indicating activation of splenic macrophages and T cells, without affecting IL-4 levels.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review major studies on Reishi's potential benefits in managing cardiometabolic disease and its risk factors.
results_summary: The abstract mentions inconsistent evidence about Reishi's potential health benefits, but specific findings are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing studies on Reishi (Ganoderma lucidum) to assess its potential in combating SARS-CoV-2 infection and related complications.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that Reishi may help manage complications of SARS-CoV-2 infection and co-morbidities, but preclinical and clinical evaluations are needed to confirm efficacy, dosage, and toxicity.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a water-soluble extract from Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) mycelia (MAK) could protect against azoxymethane-induced colon tumors in rats.
results_summary: The study found that dietary MAK significantly reduced tumor incidence and size in rats, with higher doses (2.5% MAK) showing more pronounced effects. MAK also decreased beta-catenin positive tumor cell nuclei and lowered the PCNA labeling index, suggesting chemopreventive potential.
population_specificity: Male F344/Du Crj rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a comprehensive and critical assessment of Reishi's pharmacological potential, nutritional value, and clinical evidence from preclinical and clinical studies.
results_summary: Reishi exhibits pharmacological potential in diabetes, inflammation, cancer, and other conditions, but most evidence is preclinical with notable drawbacks. Clinical data on safety, efficacy, and long-term effects are lacking despite increasing patents and trials.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical and clinical studies reviewed, but no specific population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Reishi (Ganoderma lucidum) as a therapeutic agent against SARS-CoV-2, COVID-19 pathomanifestations, and comorbid conditions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Reishi may be suitable as an anti-COVID agent, but acknowledges the study's limitations as a review rather than original research, with no concrete efficacy data provided.
population_specificity: Global population (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a molecular and clinical basis for understanding GLPS as a polysaccharide-based modern medicine with complex chemical and pharmacological properties.
results_summary: The study found that GLPS has antioxidant, anti-tumor, immune-modulatory, hypoglycemic, and hypolipidemic activities, and has been clinically used for over 40 years to treat neurosis, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, atrophic myotonia, and muscular dystrophy, as well as to improve quality of life in cancer patients during chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with neurosis, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, atrophic myotonia, muscular dystrophy, and cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
interactions: Reduces the amount of glucocorticoid required for myopathy patients in remission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a molecular and clinical basis for understanding Ganoderma lucidum polysaccharide (GLPS) as a modern medicine with complex chemical and pharmacological properties.
results_summary: GLPS has been clinically used for over forty years, showing efficacy in treating refractory myopathy, reducing glucocorticoid requirements, and improving quality of life for cancer patients during chemotherapy. It exhibits antioxidant, anti-tumor, immune-modulatory, hypoglycemic, and hypolipidemic activities.
population_specificity: Patients with refractory myopathy and cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
study_duration: Over forty years of clinical use

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Reishi extracts cause DNA damage, comparing their effects to the known DNA-intercalating agent doxorubicin.
results_summary: The study found that a purified fraction of Reishi containing fatty acids showed weak DNA-damaging activity, unlike doxorubicin, which had a clear effect. The results suggest Reishi has minimal direct DNA-damaging potential, supporting its traditional use for longevity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro bacterial assay)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the anticancer effects of G. lucidum polysaccharides (GLP) and their underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that GLP exhibits potential anticancer activity through immunomodulatory, anti-proliferative, pro-apoptotic, anti-metastatic, and anti-angiogenic effects, with no obvious toxicity reported in clinical studies.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (adjuvant therapy context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence supporting the effectiveness and safety of Reishi and other medicinal mushrooms in treating human diseases.
results_summary: The study found no scientific evidence supporting the effectiveness of Reishi or other medicinal mushrooms in treating human diseases and highlighted potential harm from natural products. It also noted the presence of potent toxins and neurotropic compounds, suggesting possible pharmacological properties that require further research.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anticancer activity of Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) by examining its effects on transcription factors NF-kappaB and AP-1, and its potential to inhibit tumor invasiveness in breast and prostate cancer cells.
results_summary: Ganoderma lucidum inhibited NF-kappaB and AP-1, leading to reduced expression of uPA and uPAR, and suppressed cell adhesion and migration in highly invasive breast and prostate cancer cells, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for reducing tumor invasiveness.
population_specificity: Highly invasive breast and prostate cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) for treating cardiovascular risk factors in adults, focusing on blood glucose, blood pressure, and lipid profiles.
results_summary: The study found no statistically or clinically significant improvements in HbA1c, total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, or body-mass index with Reishi. Some inconsistent results were noted for post-prandial blood glucose, but clinical significance remains unclear. Adverse events were more frequent with Reishi but were not serious.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the benefits and harms of family-based psychoeducation and relaxation training (FPRT) versus family-based cognitive behavioral therapy (FCBT) in youth with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
results_summary: The study design focused on reducing bias and broadening outcome measures, but the abstract does not report specific results regarding the efficacy or effects of relaxation therapy (FPRT) compared to FCBT. The primary outcome was OCD symptom severity, with secondary outcomes including quality-of-life and adverse events.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 8-17 years with a primary OCD diagnosis and a CY-BOCS score ≥16.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combining acceptance and commitment therapy with music relaxation therapy on improving mental state, mental resilience, and quality of life in college students.
results_summary: The study found that the combination therapy significantly improved psychological status, mental resilience, and quality of life scores compared to conventional interventions, with statistically significant differences post-intervention.
population_specificity: 80 college students divided into control and observation groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of relaxation therapy on sleep disturbances in cancer survivors compared to massage therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in sleep outcomes from relaxation therapy, though there were trends for improved self-reported sleep quality. The abstract concludes that relaxation therapy appears safe but lacks evidence for efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors experiencing sleep disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation therapy, alone or combined with acupoint massage, reduces postoperative fatigue in lumbar disc herniation surgical patients.
results_summary: The study compared relaxation therapy, acupoint massage, and their combination against conventional treatment, measuring fatigue and psychological outcomes, but specific results for relaxation therapy alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 180 Chinese patients with postoperative fatigue syndrome following lumbar disc herniation surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of relaxation therapy on psoriasis severity, quality of life, stress levels, and psychiatric comorbidity compared to standard dermatology treatment alone.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy combined with standard treatment significantly improved psoriasis severity (PASI 50 achieved by 70% of cases vs. 13.3% of controls) and quality of life (DLQI, HADS scores), but did not significantly reduce perceived stress.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis, assessed for stress, anxiety, depression, and quality of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation therapy could reduce benzodiazepine (BZD) use in patients with medically unexplained symptoms (MUS).
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly increased the number of patients who reduced BZD use and improved subjective MUS symptoms compared to the control group. Long-term BZD use (>6 months) was identified as a barrier to dose reduction.
population_specificity: Outpatients with medically unexplained symptoms (MUS) using benzodiazepines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of relaxation therapy on reducing depressive symptoms compared to psychotherapy or no treatment.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy showed no significant difference in reducing self-rated depressive symptoms compared to psychotherapy but was more effective than no treatment, waiting list, or minimal treatment. The meta-analysis suggests relaxation therapy may reduce depressive symptoms with an effect comparable to psychotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with depression

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of psychoeducational relaxation therapy (PRT) alone versus PRT combined with acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) for chronic pain management.
results_summary: PRT alone showed significant improvements in mental quality of life and depression compared to PRT+ACT at the end of therapy, but both interventions were equally effective at the 3-month follow-up. The study concluded that PRT is effective for chronic pain care, and adding ACT did not significantly enhance outcomes.
population_specificity: 138 patients with chronic pain.
study_duration: Duration of therapy not explicitly stated, but follow-up was 3 months post-therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation meditation during breastfeeding could improve maternal psychological state and infant growth in Chinese primiparous mothers following late preterm delivery.
results_summary: The study measured maternal stress and anxiety, infant growth, milk production, and microbiome composition, but specific results regarding the intervention's effects were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Chinese primiparous mothers who delivered late preterm infants (34 0/7-37 6/7 weeks) and planned to exclusively breastfeed.
effective_dosage: Daily audio recording with relaxation meditation during breastfeeding (specific duration not specified).
study_duration: 8 weeks (from one week to eight weeks postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of relaxation therapy in controlling or reducing tic symptoms in patients with Tourette syndrome (TS).
results_summary: Relaxation therapy decreased tic severity and/or frequency in all three reviewed studies, but it was found to be less effective compared to other behavioral techniques like self-monitoring and habit reversal. The evidence is limited due to small sample sizes and high heterogeneity across study protocols.
population_specificity: Patients with Tourette syndrome (TS), total of 40 participants across three studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of relaxation techniques for pain relief in patients undergoing abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significantly greater pain relief in patients using relaxation therapy compared to controls, with 10 out of 12 studies showing statistically significant results. However, the overall quality of the studies was not high, indicating a need for more robust RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing abdominal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of relaxation therapy, alone and combined with exercise therapy, on pain intensity, range of motion, anxiety, and quality of life in office workers with chronic lower back pain.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly reduced pain intensity and anxiety, and improved quality of life, with the greatest improvements seen when combined with exercise therapy. Range of motion also improved in groups receiving exercise therapy, either alone or combined with relaxation.
population_specificity: Office workers aged 20-50 years with chronic lower back pain.
effective_dosage: 40-45 minutes of relaxation therapy, 3 times weekly.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether awareness of comfort immediately after relaxation therapy (HRV-BF using resonant breathing) influenced participants' expectations, future quality of life (QOL), and autonomic function.
results_summary: Participants aware of comfort after therapy showed increased expectations (P=0.003), improved QOL, and increased HRV after four weeks (P<0.001), though HRV during therapy did not differ between groups (P=0.949).
population_specificity: 44 family caregivers of cancer patients who felt burdened by their caregiving work.
study_duration: Initial therapy session with follow-up after four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation therapy reduces blood pressure in hypertensive patients and improves related factors like anxiety, quality of life, and sleep.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in systolic (20mmHg) and diastolic (8mmHg) blood pressure, along with improvements in sleep quality, quality of life, and state anxiety.
population_specificity: 25 Primary Care patients with poorly controlled hypertension despite pharmacological treatment.
effective_dosage: 14 group sessions of 30 minutes each (2 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive muscle relaxation therapy could reduce dental anxiety in periodontal patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater reductions in dental anxiety, depression symptoms, blood pressure, heart rate, and salivary cortisol levels compared to the control group at both 4-week and 3-month follow-ups. Progressive muscle relaxation therapy was effective in relieving tension and anxiety in dental patients.
population_specificity: 68 periodontal patients with dental anxiety scores of ≥13.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of progressive muscle relaxation therapy and 15 minutes of oral health education once per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of 15 weeks of relaxation therapy on cytokine levels in women with fibromyalgia (FM) compared to healthy controls and resistance exercise.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy increased IL-1β and IL-1ra levels in FM patients, but changes in other cytokines were weakly correlated with clinical variables. The study found no significant anti-inflammatory effect from relaxation therapy on FM symptoms or functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 125 women with fibromyalgia (FM) and 130 age-matched healthy women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of relaxation therapy in reducing symptoms of anxiety disorders.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that relaxation therapy had a medium-high effect on reducing anxiety symptoms (Hedges' g=0.62) and significant effects on depression, phobia, and worry. Heterogeneity was noted, with subgroup analysis identifying differences based on comparison types (TAU vs. CBT).
population_specificity: People with anxiety disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence and applications of Self-Active Relaxation Therapy (SART) as a bodymind approach, comparing it with established techniques and proposing a self-regulatory framework for stress and mood management.
results_summary: SART was associated with reduced negative mood states and enhanced body awareness, with applications in diverse populations including the elderly, mothers, special needs students, and disaster recovery contexts. The therapy showed promise in clinical and community settings for psychological and developmental conditions.
population_specificity: Elderly, mothers raising children, special needs students, children adapting to school, and residents in long-term disaster recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of relaxation therapy in improving breastfeeding outcomes and its impact on infant growth and behavior.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy increased milk yield in mothers of preterm infants in two randomized trials, but the milk sampling protocol was questionable. No studies investigated effects on infant outcomes, and overall evidence was limited.
population_specificity: 311 mother-infant pairs (64 full-term, 247 preterm infants) from Europe, America, and India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hypnotic relaxation therapy could reduce anxiety levels in female breast-cancer survivors.
results_summary: Significant reductions in anxiety were observed from pre- to postintervention for each weekly session, and these reductions predicted overall anxiety decreases from baseline to the end of the intervention. Hypnotizability did not significantly influence anxiety reduction outcomes.
population_specificity: Female breast-cancer survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness meditation and relaxation therapy in managing tinnitus.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy showed statistically significant improvement in tinnitus management, though mindfulness meditation demonstrated greater efficacy. Both treatments improved outcomes except for the health status indicator.
population_specificity: Patients with tinnitus (86 recruited, 27 completed relaxation therapy).
study_duration: Duration per session not specified; total intervention involved five sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of relaxation techniques versus cognitive and behavioral therapies in reducing anxiety symptoms across different anxiety disorders.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy was found to be less effective than cognitive and behavioral therapies for post-traumatic stress disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder, but no significant difference was observed for generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, and specific phobias. The effect size favored cognitive and behavioral therapies overall, but efficacy varied by disorder type and treatment factors.
population_specificity: 2801 patients across 50 studies with various anxiety disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether relaxation therapy during breastfeeding could improve maternal psychological state, alter breast milk composition or volume, and influence infant outcomes.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that relaxation therapy would reduce maternal stress, favorably alter breast milk composition or volume, and improve infant behavior and growth, but results were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: First-time breastfeeding mothers and their newborn infants in Selangor, Malaysia.
effective_dosage: Daily audio recording during breastfeeding (specific duration not specified).
study_duration: Four home visits at 2, 6, 12, and 14 weeks postnatally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Relaxation Therapy (RT) and Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) in reducing PTSD symptoms in patients with Multiple Sclerosis.
results_summary: Relaxation Therapy was effective in reducing PTSD severity, anxiety, and depression symptoms, and improving Quality of Life, though EMDR appeared more effective in reducing the proportion of patients with PTSD. Both treatments showed benefits after 10 therapy sessions.
population_specificity: Patients with Multiple Sclerosis diagnosed with PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of hypnotic and musical relaxation therapy versus psychological consultation in reducing anxiety and depression in parents of children with cleft lip and/or palate.
results_summary: The test group receiving relaxation therapy showed significant reductions in both anxiety and depression scores, outperforming the control group receiving psychological consultation, which only showed significant improvement in anxiety. The relaxation therapy group also had higher remission rates for both anxiety and depression.
population_specificity: Parents of children with cleft lip and/or palate (n=66).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hypnotic relaxation therapy improves sexual dysfunction in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Hypnotic relaxation therapy significantly improved sexual pleasure and discomfort after 5 weekly sessions compared to an attention control, with further slight improvements at the 12-week follow-up. Total SAQ scores showed significant improvement in the treatment group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with sexual dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Progressive Relaxation Therapy in reducing perceived stress among orthopaedic trauma in-patients.
results_summary: The study found that orthopaedic patients had remarkably high perceived stress scores, suggesting a need for increased awareness of stress management techniques like Progressive Relaxation Therapy among nurses.
population_specificity: Orthopaedic trauma in-patients in selected hospitals in Chennai.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of relaxation therapy on anxiety, self-esteem, and emotional regulation in adults with intellectual disabilities in a supported employment setting.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly reduced state anxiety, improved self-esteem, and enhanced cognitive reappraisal in the intervention group, while the control group showed no changes in these variables.
population_specificity: Adults with mild or moderate intellectual disabilities working in a supported employment center in France.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of relaxation therapy (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied by 10 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) in reducing self-perceived stress, anxiety, and depression among male automotive assembly-line workers.
results_summary: PMR significantly improved stress levels (effect size=0.6) compared to the pamphlet group, with a notable group*time interaction effect (p<0.001). Depression and anxiety levels showed minimal or no reduction, as baseline levels were already low in both groups.
population_specificity: Male automotive assembly-line workers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of progressive muscle relaxation therapy (PMRT) as an adjunctive therapy for reducing depression levels in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The study found that PMRT significantly reduced depression levels in MS patients, with a 49% change attributed to the therapy. The experimental group showed decreased depression levels compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty female patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and major depressive disorder (MDD) from the MS Society of Shiraz, Iran.
effective_dosage: Twelve sessions of PMRT using Bernstein and Borkovec's method.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but twelve sessions were conducted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hypnosis/relaxation therapy compared to no/minimal treatment in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: The study found limited or no benefit of hypnosis/relaxation therapy on pain or pressure pain thresholds, but low-quality evidence suggested some benefit on maximal pain and active maximal mouth opening. The included studies had high risk of bias and provided low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) or equivalent conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of relaxation therapy (RT) compared to healing touch (HT) in improving psychosocial measures and reducing hospital length of stay for stem cell transplant (SCT) patients.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy showed improvement in psychosocial measures and a shorter hospital length of stay compared to a historical control group, though only 60% of the RT group completed the intervention. The length of stay differences were not statistically significant but could be clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 57) undergoing stem cell transplant (54% autologous, 46% allogeneic).
effective_dosage: Daily sessions while hospitalized (specific duration per session not provided).
study_duration: Duration of hospitalization (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief behavioral intervention combining education, relaxation strategies, and exercise in reducing symptoms of Night Eating Syndrome (NES).
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in NES symptoms, depression, anxiety, and perceived stress across all groups, with the greatest reduction in evening food intake observed in the progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) group. Reductions in NES scores were significantly associated with improvements in depression and perceived stress but not anxiety.
population_specificity: 44 participants diagnosed with Night Eating Syndrome (NES).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included education, PMR, and exercise sessions).
study_duration: Baseline intervention with 1- and 3-week follow-up sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Benson's relaxation technique in improving dietary and fluid adherence and biomedical markers in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in blood urea nitrogen, phosphate levels, interdialytic weight gain, and blood glucose levels in the intervention group compared to the control group after 8 weeks of relaxation therapy.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients in two units affiliated with Shiraz University of Medical Sciences, Iran.
effective_dosage: Patients listened to an audiotape of Benson's relaxation technique twice daily for 20 minutes each session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of hypnotic relaxation therapy (HRT) on cortisol levels and whether cortisol changes mediated HRT's effectiveness in reducing hot flashes.
results_summary: HRT significantly reduced early evening salivary cortisol concentrations in postmenopausal women, but cortisol changes did not mediate HRT's effects on hot flashes.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women experiencing hot flashes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation therapy (PMRT) on stress markers (cortisol, SACL score, blood pressure, heart rate) in colorectal cancer patients undergoing laparoscopic surgery.
results_summary: PMRT significantly reduced stress responses, as evidenced by lower cortisol levels, SACL scores, blood pressure, and heart rate in the experimental group compared to controls. The study concluded that PMRT provides an important basis for stress control in this population.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer patients undergoing laparoscopic surgery (n=46).
effective_dosage: PMRT was performed twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of relaxation therapy on autonomic function, pain, fatigue, and daily functioning in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome or fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Guided imagery showed acute benefits for pain relief in fibromyalgia, but other relaxation techniques lacked conclusive evidence. A multimodal approach was more effective than relaxation alone for fatigue in chronic fatigue syndrome patients. No effects on autonomic function were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (88 participants) or fibromyalgia (650 participants).
study_duration: Varied (acute effects studied in two single-session trials; other durations not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hypnotic relaxation therapy could effectively reduce hot flashes and improve sleep quality in a male patient following prostate cancer treatment.
results_summary: Posttreatment, self-reported hot flashes decreased by 94%, physiologically measured hot flashes by 100%, and sleep quality improved by 87.5%. At week 12, hot flashes remained reduced by 95%, and sleep quality improved by 37.5% over baseline.
population_specificity: 69-year-old African American male with hot flashes post-prostatectomy for prostate cancer.
effective_dosage: 7 weekly sessions of hypnotic relaxation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short-term effects of relaxation therapy on autonomic and cardiovascular functions in first-year medical students.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in heart rate, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and rate pressure product, along with improved heart rate variability indices after 6 weeks of relaxation therapy. The sympathovagal balance was directly linked to blood pressure status in the study group.
population_specificity: First-year medical students (n = 67, divided into study and control groups).
effective_dosage: Daily 1-hour practice of shavasana with soothing background music.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of relaxation therapy and cold therapy on pain reduction during chest tube removal in post-cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly reduced pain intensity immediately after chest tube removal compared to the control group, with effects comparable to cold therapy. The study found no significant difference in pain reduction between relaxation and cold therapy groups.
population_specificity: Post-cardiac surgery patients (coronary artery bypass graft) in a heart hospital in Sari, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of relaxation therapy using in-row multi-needling technique, acupotomy, and conventional acupuncture for treating superior cluneal nerve entrapment syndrome.
results_summary: The in-row multi-needling technique showed superior pain reduction and higher remarkable effective rates compared to acupotomy and conventional acupuncture, with the best results observed after 4 weeks of treatment. Patient satisfaction was also significantly higher in the multi-needling group.
population_specificity: 120 cases of superior cluneal nerve entrapment syndrome, randomized into three groups of 40 each.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment involved multi-needling, acupotomy, or conventional acupuncture techniques).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of relaxation therapies for preventing or treating preterm labor (PTL) and preventing preterm birth (PTB).
results_summary: Relaxation therapy showed some benefits in reducing maternal stress and anxiety, increasing baby birthweight, and improving delivery outcomes, but it had no significant effect on preventing PTL or PTB. The results were based on limited-quality studies with small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, including those not in preterm labor and those in preterm labor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the efficacy of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) in reducing anxiety and pruritus in patients with atopic dermatitis and to evaluate serological parameters as objective measures of PMR's efficacy.
results_summary: PMR significantly reduced pruritus, sleep loss, and state anxiety in patients with atopic dermatitis, but no significant changes were observed in serological parameters. Neuropeptide Y levels were inversely related to anxiety and pruritus at baseline.
population_specificity: 25 patients with atopic dermatitis (15 in PMR group, 10 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of computer-animated relaxation therapy on headache frequency and intensity in children with tension-type headaches and assess their experiences with the therapy.
results_summary: The study found a mean improvement of 45% in headache frequency at 3 months follow-up, significant reductions in headache frequency for all participants, and decreased Total Tenderness Score for children with frequent episodic tension-type headaches. Children reported improved body awareness and the ability to regulate bodily reactions.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-13 years diagnosed with frequent episodic or chronic tension-type headache (mean age 10.9 years).
effective_dosage: Nine-session course of modified progressive relaxation therapy assisted by computer-animated surface EMG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of relaxation therapy on reducing anxiety and pain in patients before and after total joint replacement surgery.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly reduced least pain severity scores compared to the control group, though worst and average pain levels were similar. It also lowered systolic blood pressure but did not significantly affect mean blood pressure, heart rate, or anxiety scores. Patients reported subjective benefits like relaxation and improved sleep.
population_specificity: 93 patients (average age 71) undergoing total joint replacement at a medical center in Taipei, Taiwan.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes daily of breath relaxation and guided imagery tape.
study_duration: From the day before surgery to the third postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability and utility of hypnotically-assisted relaxation (HAR) in reducing globus sensation and its effect on upper esophageal sphincter (UES) pressure.
results_summary: HAR was found acceptable by participants, with 9 of 10 subjects reporting reduced globus symptom severity post-treatment, though UES function remained unaffected.
population_specificity: 10 women (median age 51.5) with persistent globus sensation unresponsive to reflux therapy and normal imaging studies.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but involved 7 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of relaxation therapy on state anxiety, preterm labor stress, and physiological measures (blood pressure, skin temperature, pulse rate) in pregnant women with preterm labor, as well as fetal heart rate.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly reduced state anxiety, preterm labor stress, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and pulse rate while increasing skin temperature in the experimental group compared to controls. No significant effect was observed on fetal heart rate.
population_specificity: 55 pregnant women with preterm labor (no other complications), hospitalized between May 2009 and January 2010.
effective_dosage: Not specified (relaxation therapy applied for 5 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a relaxation training program on the health-related quality of life of Chinese patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: The relaxation training program led to statistically significant improvements in psychological and social health-related quality of life compared to the control group, with the most notable effects occurring during the first evaluative endpoints.
population_specificity: Chinese patients with chronic heart failure, aged over 60 years.
effective_dosage: Two relaxation training sessions, one skill revision workshop, twice daily self-practice, and biweekly telephone follow-up.
study_duration: 14 weeks (measurements taken at discharge, 8th, and 14th weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic principles and existing literature on relaxation therapy's effects for treating neurogenic communication or cognitive disorders, including dementia.
results_summary: The abstract notes that relaxation therapy has shown positive effects for certain physical conditions like chronic pain and anxiety, but empirical evidence for neurogenic disorders is limited. The review summarizes existing research but does not provide specific efficacy data for relaxation therapy in this context.
population_specificity: Patients with neurogenic communication or cognitive disorders, including dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a cardiac rehabilitation program with relaxation therapy (CPRT) versus cardiac rehabilitation alone (CPA) on psychological stress, hemodynamic variables, cardiac risk factors, and hospital admissions in coronary artery disease patients.
results_summary: CPRT significantly reduced perceived stress, heart rate, blood pressure, and rate-pressure product values compared to CPA. Both groups improved smoking status, physical activity, BMI, and cholesterol levels, but hospital admission rates did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease (N = 81).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of progressive muscle relaxation training (PMRT) on psychological distress and symptom status in older Chinese patients with heart failure.
results_summary: PMRT showed a medium effect on reducing psychological distress but only a nonsignificant trend in improving symptom status (dyspnea and fatigue). The study concluded that PMRT may be useful as an adjunctive nonpharmacologic treatment for heart failure.
population_specificity: Older Chinese patients with heart failure.
effective_dosage: Two PMRT sessions, one revision workshop, twice-daily home practices, and biweekly telephone follow-up calls.
study_duration: 14 weeks (measurements at baseline, 8th week, and 14th week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether relaxation therapy, as an adjunct to standard drug treatment, improves blood pressure control in patients with moderate to severe hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that relaxation therapy combined with standard antihypertensive drugs led to significantly better blood pressure control (59% vs. 36%) and greater reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to standard therapy alone.
population_specificity: 220 patients with newly diagnosed essential moderate to severe hypertension requiring drug therapy.
effective_dosage: Relaxation therapy administered 2 times per week.

study_goal: To examine the effects of relaxation therapy on psychological outcomes and disease-specific quality of life in older heart failure patients.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy significantly improved psychological outcomes, particularly reducing depression, and enhanced disease-specific quality of life, including dyspnea, fatigue, and emotional well-being, compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Older heart failure patients
effective_dosage: Two training sessions, one revision workshop, and twice-daily taped-directed home relaxation practice with bi-weekly telephone support

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of Muscle Relaxation Therapy (MRT) techniques in treating anxiety disorders, particularly panic disorder (PD) and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), and to explore their physiological basis.
results_summary: The study found that abbreviated MRT techniques are effective in treating PD and GAD, though physiological activation did not consistently decrease despite patients reporting reduced anxiety. Better-designed studies are needed to understand MRT's mechanisms.
population_specificity: Patients with panic disorder (PD) and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review relaxation therapy as a complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) for treating neurogenic cognitive or communicative disorders.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes and critiques existing research on relaxation therapy but does not provide specific efficacy results, indicating a need for further empirical investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with neurogenic cognitive or communicative disorders.

study_goal: To determine the effects of relaxation therapy on recovery from cardiac ischemic events and its role in secondary prevention.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy improved physiological outcomes (e.g., reduced resting heart rate, increased heart rate variability), psychological outcomes (e.g., reduced state anxiety and depression), and cardiac effects (e.g., reduced angina and arrhythmia). Intensive supervised relaxation showed significant benefits, while abbreviated therapy had minimal or no effects.
population_specificity: Patients with myocardial ischemia.
effective_dosage: Abbreviated (3 h or less), full (9 h supervised), and expanded (11 h with cognitive therapy).
study_duration: Varied by study (3 h to 11 h of instruction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of relaxation therapy on exercise capacity and quality of life in female patients with coronary syndrome X.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy improved health-related quality of life (measured by SCI and SIP) and tolerated exertion during walking but did not enhance exercise capacity (VO2max, work rate, or distance walked).
population_specificity: Female patients aged 41-65 years with coronary syndrome X.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of biofeedback-assisted relaxation therapy (BFRT) on symptoms of neurocardiogenic syncope, including headache and loss of consciousness, and to assess the influence of coping styles on treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in headache index and loss of consciousness in the BFRT group compared to controls, with both groups showing reductions in state anxiety and depression. However, participants generally exhibited illness overreaction and nonadherence tendencies, suggesting coping style may influence outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with neurocardiogenic syncope (22 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment included electromyograph and thermal biofeedback, autogenic and progressive relaxation, and symptom-specific recommendations).
study_duration: 2-week intervention period (plus 2-week pretest and posttreatment/control periods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of relaxation therapy (e.g., progressive relaxation, autogenic training, yoga) in improving lung function, symptoms, medication use, and healthcare utilization in adult asthma patients.
results_summary: The review found generally negligible effects of relaxation therapy on lung function, symptoms, medication consumption, and healthcare use. Methodological deficiencies, such as small sample sizes and suboptimal data analysis, limited the reliability of the findings.
population_specificity: Adult asthma patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of cognitive behavior therapy versus relaxation therapy for patients with chronic fatigue syndrome.
results_summary: At the 5-year follow-up, 36% of patients who received relaxation therapy rated themselves as "much improved" or "very much improved," significantly fewer than those who received cognitive behavior therapy. Relaxation therapy showed fewer patients meeting criteria for complete recovery, experiencing steady symptom improvement, or maintaining mild/absent symptoms post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (60 initially, 53 at follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of relaxation therapy in improving interoception and symptom recognition for better self-management in chronic conditions, particularly in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that relaxation therapy enhances accurate symptom recognition and attribution, aiding in effective coping and self-management of chronic conditions like asthma, diabetes, atopic dermatitis, and epilepsy. It also noted potential benefits in fostering autonomy and self-esteem in young patients.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with chronic conditions (e.g., asthma, diabetes, atopic dermatitis, epilepsy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare daytime functioning in college students with and without insomnia and assess the impact of progressive relaxation (PR) treatment on sleep and daytime functioning in students with insomnia.
results_summary: PR improved sleep in treated students with insomnia compared to untreated students, but no significant improvements in daytime functioning were observed. The study suggests insomnia treatments focused on sleep may not immediately enhance daytime functioning.
population_specificity: College students with insomnia (SWI; n=57) and without insomnia (SNI; n=61).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mood state (depression, anxiety, and daily hassles) on the outcome of biofeedback-assisted relaxation in individuals with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in blood glucose levels between the biofeedback-assisted relaxation group and the control group. However, treatment success correlated with lower depression, anxiety, and hassles scores, suggesting mood impacts relaxation therapy outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (18 subjects total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation therapy could improve preterm labor outcomes, including gestational age at birth, pregnancy prolongation, and birth weight.
results_summary: The experimental group practicing daily relaxation had significantly longer gestations and larger newborns compared to control and nonadherent groups, indicating a positive effect of relaxation therapy on preterm labor outcomes.
population_specificity: 107 women with singleton gestations, documented contractions with cervical change, and intact membranes.
effective_dosage: Daily progressive relaxation exercise using provided tapes.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key themes for successful implementation of mental practice (MP) in surgical training, including the role of relaxation therapy in enhancing mental imagery.
results_summary: The study found that relaxation therapy can augment high-quality mental imagery, which is fundamental to successful mental practice in surgical training. It suggests relaxation therapy may improve surgical performance and reduce anxiety, though real-world application needs further research.
population_specificity: Postgraduate surgical trainees

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a relaxation therapy involving rhythmically dominated music could synchronize heart rate and improve relaxation, sleep, and pain management in cancer patients.
results_summary: Trained patients showed increased synchronization of heart rate with musical beat, improved relaxation, reduced pain, better sleep onset, and decreased analgesic use. The highest synchronization correlated with the best-reported relaxation and analgesic effects.
population_specificity: 28 patients with chronic cancer pain in a stable phase of the disease.
effective_dosage: 30-minute lullaby-like music sessions with gradually decreasing tempi (48-42 beats per min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding relaxation therapy to exercise training reduces cardiac events and hospitalizations in post-myocardial infarction patients.
results_summary: Relaxation therapy combined with exercise training reduced cardiac events (20% vs. 33%) and hospitalizations (31% reduction) compared to exercise alone, with lower odds ratios for adverse outcomes.
population_specificity: Post-myocardial infarction patients (n = 156).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of Yu Melody relaxation training (YMRT) combined with Jianpi Jieyu Decoction (JJD) in treating patients with insomnia disorders (ID).
results_summary: YMRT combined with JJD significantly improved sleep quality and reduced depressive and anxiety symptoms compared to JJD alone, with no significant difference in adverse events between groups. The combined therapy showed superior efficacy in reducing Insomnia Severity Index (ISI), Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item (GAD-7), and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) scores.
population_specificity: 94 ID patients from Xiyuan Hospital, China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention with a 2-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of immersive VR-assisted relaxation therapy on patients with depression in Parkinson's disease (DPD).
results_summary: The study proposes that VR-assisted training could improve DPD, offering an alternative to traditional psychotherapy, which has limited accessibility. The outcomes will be measured using depression scales, health surveys, neuroinflammation factors, and functional MRI.
population_specificity: Patients with depression in Parkinson's disease (DPD).
effective_dosage: VR-assisted training (40 min) three times a week.
